case_name: Hiralal Patni v. Seth Loonkaran Sethiya

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 110 of 1961 was filed by special leave against the judgment and order dated October 14, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.110 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 14, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal from Order No. 41 of 1959.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court confirmed the order of Civil Judge, Agra, directing Official Receiver to take possession of appellant's property.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment dated October 14, 1960, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad confirming the order passed by the Civil Judge, Agra, directing the Official Receiver to take possession of the property of the appellant.

facts.text: There were three spinning mills and one flour mill at Agra, collectively known as Johns Mills, originally owned by John family or predecessors.

anchor.surface_text: At Agra, there were three spinning mills and one flour mill, all of which together were described as the Johns Mills and, originally, the John family or their predecessors were the owners of all these mills.

facts.text: Joint owners of the mills at initiation of proceedings: Hiralal Patni and Munni Lal Mehra held 19/40th share.

anchor.surface_text: The following persons were the joint owners of the mills  1  Hiralal Patni, the appellant, and Munni Lal Mehrt 19/40th share

facts.text: Gambhirmal Pandiya Private Ltd held 8/40th share in the mills.

anchor.surface_text: 2  Gambhirmal Pandiya Private Ltd 8/40th share

facts.text: Messrs. John Co held 11/40th share in the mills.

anchor.surface_text: 3  Messrs. John Co 11/40th share and

facts.text: I.E. John held 2/40th share in the mills.

anchor.surface_text: 4  I.E. John 2/40th share.

facts.text: Seth Loonkaran Sethiya (respondent No. 1) advanced large amounts to Messrs. John Co on security of its business assets and stocks.

anchor.surface_text: Seth Loonkaran Sethiya, respondent No. 1, advanced large amounts to Messrs. John Co. on the security of its business assets and stocks.

facts.text: Sethiya filed O.S. No. 76 of 1949 on April 18, 1949, in Civil Judge, Agra, against John Co for recovery by sale of assets.

anchor.surface_text: On April 18, 1949, the said Sethiya filed 0. S. No. 76 of 1949 in the Court of the Civil Judge, Agra, against John Co. for the recovery of the amount due to him by sale of the assets of the said company.

facts.text: Parties to suit O.S. 76/1949: partners of John Co (defendants 1st set), partners of Johns Jain Co (defendants 2nd set).

anchor.surface_text: To that suit the partners of Messrs. John Co., for convenience described as defendants 1st set, and the partners of Messrs. Johns Jain Co., who were for convenience described as defendants 2nd set, were made parties.

facts.text: Pending suit, Sethiya applied under O. XL r.1 CPC for appointment of Receiver.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the suit, the said Sethiya filed an application, under O. XL, r. 1, Code of Civil Procedure, for the appointment of a Receiver.

facts.text: Civil Judge, Agra appointed two joint Receivers on May 21, 1949, to run the three spinning mills.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated May 21, 1949, the learned Civil Judge appointed two joint Receivers and directed them to run the three spinning mills.

facts.text: Hiralal Patni appealed the receiver appointment order to Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal Patni filed an appeal against that order to the High Court at Allahabad,

facts.text: Allahabad HC modified Civil Judge's order on August 22, 1949, confining receivers to share of John Co.

anchor.surface_text: and the said Court by its order dated August 22, 1949, modified the order of the Civil Judge confining the order of appointment of Receivers only to the share of Messrs. John Co. in John Jain Mehre Co.

facts.text: Civil Judge on December 1, 1951, directed receivers to take possession of Hiralal Patni's share in the mills.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Civil Judge by his order dated December 1, 1951, directed the Receivens to take possession of the appellants share in the mills also

facts.text: Appeal against December 1, 1951 order was stayed by High Court pending disposal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order an appeal was preferred to the High Court and the operation of the said order was stayed pending the disposal of the- appeal.

facts.text: Civil Judge passed preliminary decree on April 5, 1954, directing deposit of Rs. 18,00,152 or sale of assets.

anchor.surface_text: On April 5, 1954, the Civil Judge passed a preliminary decree against the defendants therein directing them to deposit the decree amount in court within the prescribed time, and in default the plaintiff was given a right to apply for a final decree for sale of the business assets of the defendants.

facts.text: Preliminary decree directed receivers to continue until discharged.

anchor.surface_text: The preliminary decree directed that the Receivers should continue on the property until discharged.

facts.text: Hiralal Patni appealed the preliminary decree to High Court and sought stay.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal Patni preferred a appeal to the High Court against the said preliminary decree and applied for interim stay of its operation.

facts.text: High Court on August 23, 1955, discharged previous receivers and appointed new receiver.

anchor.surface_text: On August 23, 1955, the High Court discharged the Receiver,, appointed by the learned. Civil Judge, and appointed another Receiver in their place.

facts.text: Civil Judge prepared scheme for running mills on March 25, 1955; parties appealed to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On March 25, 1955, the learned Civil Judge prepared a scheme for running the mills, and the parties preferred appeals against that scheme to the High Court.

facts.text: Appeals against scheme compromised; parties agreed to lease mills from receiver for three years.

anchor.surface_text: The said appeals were compromised and under the term-, of the compromise the parties agreed to take different mills on lease for a period of three years from the Receiver.

facts.text: Receiver executed lease of flour mill to Hiralal Patni on January 14, 1956, for three years.

anchor.surface_text: On January 14, 1956, the Receiver executed a lease in respect of the flour mill in favour of Hiralal Patni for a period of three years.

facts.text: Lease deed required Patni to deliver premises to Receiver upon expiry.

anchor.surface_text: Under the lease deed it was agreed that he should deliver the demised premises to the Receiver upon the expiry of the term.

facts.text: Final decree for sale of properties made on March 14, 1956, silent on receiver.

anchor.surface_text: In due course, on March 14, 1956, a final decree was made in the suit for the sale of the properties, but the final decree was silent in regard to the Receiver appointed earlier.

facts.text: Hiralal Patni applied to High Court on September 29, 1958, for extension of lease by three years.

anchor.surface_text: On September 29, 1958, Hiralal Patni applied to the High Court for extension of the lease by three years.

facts.text: High Court rejected lease extension on January 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On January 16, 1959, the High, Court rejected the application on the ground that the lease was only a stopgap arrangement

facts.text: Receiver applied to Civil Judge on January 17, 1959, for instructions to dispossess appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On January 17, 1959, the Receiver applied to the Civil Judge for instructions whether he should proceed at once to dispossess the appellant.

facts.text: Hiralal Patni objected to dispossession, claiming ownership possession.

anchor.surface_text: On notice, Hiralal Patni raised various objections and claimed that he was entitled to remain in possession of the property as its owner.

facts.text: Civil Judge disallowed Patni's objections, directed receiver to auction flour mill for two years.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge disallowed his objections and held that the Receiver derived his authority from the preliminary decree, and directed the Receiver to lease out the said flour mill by auction for a period of two years.

facts.text: Auction held; Hiralal Patni highest bidder, paid and executed lease.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to that order, an auction was held, and the appellant was the highest bidder, and he paid the lease amount and executed a formal lease deed.

facts.text: Patni appealed Civil Judge's order to High Court; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Not satisfied with the order of the Civil Judge, Hiralal Patni preferred an appeal to the High Court. The High Court in an elaborate judgment considered the contentions raised on behalf of Hiralal Patni and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Preliminary decree amount was Rs. 18,00,152.

anchor.surface_text: deposit a sum of Rs. 18,00,152 in court

facts.text: Application for discharge of receiver pending in lower court.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it has been brought to our notice that an application for the discharge of the Receiver is pending in the lower court.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 14, 1960,
under O. XL, r. 1, Code of Civil Procedure, for the appointment of a Receiver.

anchor.surface_text: The material provisions of Order XL of the Code of Civil Procedure read Rule 1. (1) Where it appears to the Court to be just and convenient, the Court may by order- (b) remove any person from the possession or custody of the property (d) confer upon the receiver all such powers, as to bringing and defending suits and for the realization, management, protection, preservation and improvement of the property, the collection of the rents and profits thereof Nothing in this rule shall authorize the Court to remove from the possession or custody of property any person whom any party to the suit has number a present right so to remove.

concepts.interpretation: Court can direct receiver to remove party to suit from possession even without plaintiff's present right; limited only for non-parties.

concepts.interpretation: Does not prescribe automatic termination of receivership.

anchor.surface_text: The law may briefly be stated thus 1 If a receiver is appointed in a suit until judgment, the appointment is brought to an end by the judgment in the action. 2 If a receiver is appointed in a suit, with. out his tenure being expressly defined, he will continue to be receiver till he is discharged. 3 But, after the final disposal of the suit as between the parties to the litigation, the receivers functions are usually terminated, he would still be answerable to the court as its officer till he is finally discharged 4 The court has ample power to continue the receiver even after the final decree if the exigencies of the case so require.

concepts.interpretation: Receiver continues until discharged unless expressly limited; court may continue post-decree; functions terminate post-suit but accountable until discharge.

issues.text: On a true construction of the relevant orders, does the Receiver have power to dispossess the appellant in such a way as to prevent him from working his flour mill?

anchor.surface_text: 1  On a true construction of the relevant orders the Receiver has no power to dispossess the appellant in such a way as to prevent him from working his flour mill.

issues.text: After the passing of the final decree, can the Receiver exercise powers in respect of the rights of the parties, or does he cease automatically on termination of the suit?

anchor.surface_text: 2  After the passing of the final decree, though the Receiver may continue for the purpose of accounting and discharge of debts, he cannot exercise any powers in respect of the rights of the parties.

issues.text: Can the appellant, who acquired a right under a lease deed from the Receiver and continued in possession after its expiry, be dispossessed only by a suit and not by a summary procedure?

anchor.surface_text: 3  in any view, as the appellant acquired a right under a lease deed and continued in possession after its expiry, he could be dispossessed only by a suit and not by a summary procedure.

issues.text: Does a Receiver appointed in a suit cease to be such automatically on the termination of the suit?

anchor.surface_text: This contention leads us to the consideration of the question whether a Receiver appointed in a suit ceases to be such automatically on the termination of the suit.

issues.text: In the circumstances of this case, could the Receiver recover possession from the appellant only by instituting a regular suit against him for eviction?

anchor.surface_text: The third contention of learned counsel for the appellant raises the question whether in the circumstances of this case the Receiver could recover possession from the appellant only by instituting a regular suit against him for eviction.

arguments.claim: Receiver continues to be receiver till he is discharged unless tenure expressly defined; court may continue post-final decree if exigencies require.

anchor.surface_text: The law may briefly be stated thus  1 If a receiver is appointed in a suit until judgment, the appointment is brought to an end by the judgment in the action.  2 If a receiver is appointed in a suit, without his tenure being expressly defined, he will continue to be receiver till he is discharged.

arguments.claim: Flour mill of the appellant was put in the possession of the Receiver and appellant was running it under compromise formula.

anchor.surface_text: We hold on a construction of the relevant orders that the flour mill of the appellant was also put in the possession of the Receiver and that the appellant was running the said mill under the compromise formula.

arguments.claim: Receivers continued by the preliminary decree are entitled to function till discharged.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we are definitely of the opinion that the Receivers continued by the preliminary decree are entitled to function in that capacity till they are discharged.

arguments.claim: Court was legally competent to confer power on Receiver under O. XL r.1(1)(d) to recover property from appellant summarily.

anchor.surface_text: The court, in our view, was legally competent to confer a power on the Receiver under Order XL, r. 1 (1) (d), of the Code of Civil Procedure to recover the property from the appellant.

holdings.text: We hold on a construction of the relevant orders that the flour mill of the appellant was also put in the possession of the Receiver and that the appellant was running the said mill under the compromise formula.

anchor.surface_text: We hold on a construction of the relevant orders that the flour mill of the appellant was also put in the possession of the Receiver and that the appellant was running the said mill under the compromise formula.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examines chain of orders appointing receivers over shares, compromise for leasing mills from receiver, and lease deed acknowledging receiver's possession to conclude flour mill was under receiver's possession.

holdings.text: In the circumstances, we are definitely of the opinion that the Receivers continued by the preliminary decree are entitled to function in that capacity till they are discharged.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we are definitely of the opinion that the Receivers continued by the preliminary decree are entitled to function in that capacity till they are discharged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preliminary decree expressly directs receivers to continue until discharged; final decree silent and does not terminate suit as personal decree possible; applies principles from authorities that receivership endures until discharge.

holdings.text: The law may briefly be stated thus: 1 If a receiver is appointed in a suit until judgment, the appointment is brought to an end by the judgment in the action. 2 If a receiver is appointed in a suit, without his tenure being expressly defined, he will continue to be receiver till he is discharged. 3 But, after the final disposal of the suit as between the parties to the litigation, the receivers functions are usually terminated, he would still be answerable to the court as its officer till he is finally discharged 4 The court has ample power to continue the receiver even after the final decree if the exigencies of the case so require.

anchor.surface_text: The law may briefly be stated thus  1 If a receiver is appointed in a suit until judgment, the appointment is brought to an end by the judgment in the action.  2 If a receiver is appointed in a suit, with. out his tenure being expressly defined, he will continue to be receiver till he is discharged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizes principles from Halsbury, Kerr, High, Woodroffe on duration of receivership, applying to facts where no express termination and preliminary decree mandates continuance.

holdings.text: Where it appears to the Court to be just and convenient, the Court may by order- (b) remove any person from the possession or custody of the property (d) confer upon the receiver all such powers... Nothing in this rule shall authorize the Court to remove from the possession or custody of property any person whom any party to the suit has not a present right so to remove.

anchor.surface_text: The material provisions of Order XL of the Code of Civil Procedure read Rule 1. (1) Where it appears to the Court to be just and convenient, the Court may by order- (b) remove any person from the possession or custody of the property (d) confer upon the receiver all such powers,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of O. XL r.1(1)(b)(d) proviso: court/receiver may remove party to suit from possession even absent plaintiff's present right; limitation only for non-parties.

holdings.text: Even though the lease deed stands in favour of the receiver the express undertaking given by the lessee for an unconditional surrender of the property is in favour of the court The summary enforcement of the undertaking thus taken by the court is only a step towards the discharge of the duties of the court.

anchor.surface_text: the Court could summarily evict him. The learned Judge made the following observations at p. 39 Even though the lease deed stands in favour of the receiver the express undertaking given by the lessee for an unconditional surrender of the property is in favour of the court The summary enforcement of the undertaking thus taken by the court is only a, step towards the discharge of the duties of the court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lessee's express surrender undertaking in lease to receiver is enforceable summarily by court as part of estate administration duties; distinguishes cases requiring suit for independent lessees.

holdings.text: The court, in our view, was legally competent to confer a power on the Receiver under Order XL, r. 1 (1) (d), of the Code of Civil Procedure to recover the property from the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The court, in our view, was legally competent to confer a power on the Receiver under Order XL, r. 1 (1) (d), of the Code of Civil Procedure to recover the property from the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant as suit party under expired lease with surrender clause; court invokes O. XL r.1 powers for summary recovery in administration context, no suit needed.

precedents.citation: Krista Chandra Ghose v. Krista Sakha Ghose 1 ... 1908 I.L.R. 36 Cal. 52.

anchor.surface_text: Krista Chandra Ghose v. Krista Sakha Ghose  1  is a case where a lease was granted by a Receiver acting under an order of companyrt and the possession of the property had been given to the lessee, and subsequently certain parties applied to the companyrt for a declaration that the lease was invalid on the ground that it was obtained by companylusion.

precedents.case_name: Krista Chandra Ghose v. Krista Sakha Ghose
precedents.cited_proposition: summary order could not be passed to set aside the lease granted by a Receiver and the proper remedy would be by a suit against the Receiver and the lessee

anchor.surface_text: The Rajasthan High Court in Nanakchand v. Pannalal  2  held that a Receiver companyld number recover the rent from a lessee in a summary order of the companyrt, but should file a suit just like any other landlord.

precedents.cited_proposition: a Receiver could not recover the rent from a lessee in a summary order of the court, but should file a suit just like any other landlord

precedents.citation: Loonkaran v. I. N. John 3 ... A.I.R. 1961 All. 59.

anchor.surface_text: The Allahabad High Court in Loonkaran v. I. N. John  3 , though it conceded that where a lease had been executed by the Receiver, the lessee may ordinarily be evicted from the demised property only by a regular suit, held that where after the expiry of the term of the lease granted by a Receiver, the sub. lessee in possession gave an undertaking to the companyrt that he would vacate the premises in favour of the prospective lessee if numberfresh lease was granted in his favour, the companyrt has power to eject the sub-leessee in its summary jurisdiction.

precedents.cited_proposition: where after the expiry of the term of the lease granted by a Receiver, the sub-lessee gave an undertaking to vacate, the court has power to eject the sub-lessee in its summary jurisdiction
precedents.cited_holding: By giving an undertaking to the court that he would vacate the Mill in favour of the prospective lessee and by bidding in the court-auction the appellant submitted himself to the jurisdiction of the court. The appellant could therefore be ejected by summary process, instead of by a suit.

precedents.citation: Sivarajan v. Official Beceiver, Quilon District 1 ... I.L.R. 1953 T.C. 30.

anchor.surface_text: So too, the High Court of Travancore-Cochin in Sivarajan v. Official Beceiver, Quilon District  1  held that where the period of the lease granted to the receiver had already expired and as per the express stipulation in the lease deed the lessee was bound to surrender possession of the property without raising any objection at all, the Court could summarily evict him.

precedents.case_name: Sivarajan v. Official Receiver, Quilon District
precedents.cited_proposition: where the period of the lease granted by the receiver had expired and the lease deed stipulated unconditional surrender of possession, the court could summarily evict the lessee
precedents.cited_holding: Even though the lease deed stands in favour of the receiver the express undertaking given by the lessee for an unconditional surrender of the property is in favour of the court. The summary enforcement of the undertaking thus taken by the court is only a step towards the discharge of the duties of the court in the management of the estate.

justification_sets.label: Receivership Continuance and Termination Principles support

outcome.relief_summary: Contentions of appellant rejected; Receiver held entitled to possession of flour mill; lower courts' orders upheld allowing Receiver to dispossess appellant summarily
directions: Any observations that we have made in this judgment are not intended to affect the merits one way or other in the disposal of that application [for discharge of Receiver].
That application will be disposed of in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The law may briefly be stated thus  1 If a receiver is appointed in a suit until judgment, the appointment is brought to an end by the judgment in the action.  2 If a receiver is appointed in a suit, with. out his tenure being expressly defined, he will continue to be receiver till he is discharged.

The law may briefly be stated thus  1 If a receiver is appointed in a suit until judgment, the appointment is brought to an end by the judgment in the action.  2 If a receiver is appointed in a suit, with. out his tenure being expressly defined, he will continue to be receiver till he is discharged.
